data.title: Navigating Away/Back To Working Tree View Resets Scrollbar Position

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.16
- OS Version: KDE Arch Kernel v4.12

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open up a working tree view of a file you have made changes to in a git repository
2. Scroll to a place you'd like to reference continually in working tree file
3. Switch tabs to another open file
4. Switch back to the working tree tab from before, note that you are teleported to the first diff present in the file and away from the location you wish to reference

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Revisit usages of Uri#file
data.body:
For remote-resource support we need to be revisit our `Uri#file`-usage because not everything is a file anymore. Often code like this is encountered 

```ts
üëé URI.file(join(sourceUri.fsPath, yetAnotherPath)) 
``` 
which unfortunately steals everything else from the "source" uri, like scheme, fragment and query. The way such conversions should be is: 

```ts
üëç source.with({ path: join(source.path, yetAnotherPath) })
```

I have done an initial scan and places we should check are

* [x] vs/workbench/parts/execution/electron-browser/execution.contribution.ts#L194
* [x] vs/workbench/parts/files/browser/fileActions.ts#L309
* [x] vs/workbench/parts/files/browser/views/explorerView.ts#L454
* [x] vs/workbench/parts/files/common/editors/fileEditorTracker.ts#L209
* [x] vs/workbench/parts/output/common/outputLinkComputer.ts#L73
* [x] vs/workbench/parts/search/browser/searchActions.ts#L379
* [x] vs/workbench/parts/search/common/queryBuilder.ts#L198
* [x] vs/workbench/services/editor/browser/editorService.ts#L236
* [x] vs/workbench/services/telemetry/common/workspaceStats.ts#L230
* [x] vs/workbench/services/textfile/common/textFileService.ts#L454
* [x] vs/base/browser/dnd.ts#L71
* [x] vs/base/common/labels.ts#L37

data.title: Extract Function Uses Wrong Indentation
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.16.0
- OS Version: macOS 10.12.6

Steps to Reproduce:

Config info that might apply:
Project is using the Prettier plugin, which has a default tab size of 2. 
I have set `"editor.tabSize": 2` in my workspace settings. I also tried setting it in user settings, but same results.

1. Create a new test.ts file with these contents:
```javascript
export class TestClass {
  private thing1 = true;
  private thing2 = false;

  public doSomething = () => {
    this.thing1 = !this.thing2;
    this.thing2 = !this.thing1;
  };
}
```
2. Highlight the two lines in doSomething and use the new (rad) extract function capability. (I was using the keyboard, FWIW.)

Actual:
```javascript
export class TestClass {
  private thing1 = true;
  private thing2 = false;

  public doSomething = () => {
      this.newFunction();
  };

    private newFunction() {
        this.thing1 = !this.thing2;
        this.thing2 = !this.thing1;
    }
}
```

Note the extra indent for both the newFunction and the call to new function.

Expected:
```javascript
export class TestClass {
  private thing1 = true;
  private thing2 = false;

  public doSomething = () => {
    this.newFunction();
  };

  private newFunction() {
    this.thing1 = !this.thing2;
    this.thing2 = !this.thing1;
  }
}
```

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Windows Integrated shell includes double quote in sent arguments

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.16.0 (787b31c0474e6165390b5a5989c9619e3e16f953, 2017-09-06T16:27:49.891Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.15063
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
project-manager|ale|0.21.1
npm-intellisense|chr|1.3.0
path-intellisense|chr|1.4.2
vscode-markdownlint|Dav|0.10.1
vscode-eslint|dba|1.3.1
vscode-instant-markdown|dba|1.3.0
githistory|don|0.2.3
gitlens|eam|5.0.0
vscode-npm-script|eg2|0.2.1
prettier-vscode|esb|0.23.1
flow-for-vscode|flo|0.7.1
vscode-docker|Pet|0.0.16
vscode-icons|rob|7.12.0
JavaScriptSnippets|xab|1.4.1
ReactSnippets|xab|1.4.0



---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open user settings
2. Add the following settings to initialize the integrated command prompt with nodejs env
```javascript
  "terminal.integrated.shell.windows": "C:\\WINDOWS\\System32\\CMD.exe",
  "terminal.integrated.shellArgs.windows": [
    "/K C:\\Progra~1\\nodejs\\nodevars.bat && set NODE_ENV=development"
  ]
```
3. Save the file
4. Press `CTRL+~` to get the command prompt up
5. Execute command `echo %NODE_ENV%`
6. It will display the string including the trailing double quote
```
Your environment has been set up for using Node.js 8.2.1 (x64) and npm.

D:\git\myproject>echo %NODE_ENV%
development"

D:\git\myproject>
```
7. It should not include the double quote
8. Workaround is to include a dummy env var that no one will ever use
```
"/K C:\\Progra~1\\nodejs\\nodevars.bat && set NODE_ENV=development && set QQQ="
```

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Do expressions error
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.17.0-insider (06529dbcacb796d59e7fc2ca0ac5dbe7c29c099e, 2017-09-13T09:50:23.560Z) - OS Version: Windows_NT x64 6.1.7601 - Extensions: Extension|Author (truncated)|Version ---|---|--- vscode-eslint|dba|1.3.1 file-icons|fil|1.0.5 easy-icons|jam|0.3.1 vetur|oct|0.9.7 (1 theme extensions excluded) --- Steps to Reproduce: 1. Use the stage-0 babel preset (or the [transform-do-expressions](https://babeljs.io/docs/plugins/transform-do-expressions/) plugin). 2. Write some JSX with do expressions. For example: ```jsx return
{do { if (test) { Hello } }}
``` Or in plain JS: ```javascript const msg = do { if (test) { 'HELLO' } else { 'MEOW' } } ``` Reproduces without extensions: **Yes** --- Code using do expressions breaks intellisense and make the code underlined in red with a "Expected expression" message. ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2798204/30377278-75b3c6ae-988f-11e7-8642-bc21d47e8d67.png)

data.title: vscode-node-debug extension w/security vulnerability included in latest release
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.16
- OS Version: N/A

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Download the ZIP version (https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?Linkid=850641)
2. Open the archive to the path \resources\app\extensions\ms-vscode.node-debug
3. Inspect the version number in package.json

This version of vscode-node-debug is 1.16.9 which includes the version of brace-extension (1.1.6) containing the ReDoS vulnerability (https://nodesecurity.io/advisories/338).  Version 1.1.7 of brace-expansion (https://github.com/juliangruber/brace-expansion/issues/33) corrected the issue and subsequently version 1.17.3 of vscode-node-debug.

data.title: Slow configuration model merging
data.body: We have seen a slowdown in startup performance with 1.16. The profiler shows that are spending much more time in `array.forEach` which we could eventually track back to being called ~10000 times from object clone which is often called from the configuration model merging. Individual calls are usually sub millisecond but this is death by thousand paper cuts... Apply the attached patch and see output like below [patch.txt](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/files/1298980/patch.txt)

data.title: Multi-root workspace git changes indicator
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.16.0 (787b31c0474e6165390b5a5989c9619e3e16f953, 2017-09-06T16:19:37.192Z)
- OS Version: Linux x64 4.10.0-33-generic
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
xml|Dot|1.9.2
beautify|Hoo|1.1.1
latex-workshop|Jam|3.5.2
npm-intellisense|chr|1.3.0
path-intellisense|chr|1.4.2
gitignore|cod|0.5.0
python|don|0.7.0
vscode-npm-script|eg2|0.2.1
vscode-auto-open-markdown-preview|hnw|0.0.4
HTMLHint|mka|0.3.3
cpptools|ms-|0.12.4
vscode-csstree|sme|0.2.0
easysass|spo|0.0.6
code-spell-checker|str|1.3.9
vscode-arduino|vsc|0.2.6
vscode-react-native|vsm|0.4.1

(1 theme extensions excluded)


---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Have a multi-root workspace with multiple git repositories in there
2. Change a file
3. Now you see in the activity bar on the left on the "Source Control" icon an indicator that one file was changed
4. Click on that "Source Control" icon
5. Now I see a collapsible list of all the repositories in the workspace
6. I have collapsed them to get a better overview
7. Now I can't see on what repository the changes were made. Not a single subtle indicator is there to guide me to the right one. Of course I usually should know what changes I just made but what if a was away for launch and come back to commit everything and start working somewhere else. In that case I would have to click through all the repositories just to find the one with the changes. 

Reproduces without extensions: Yes

---

Proposed solution:

1. Let the indicator on the "Source Control" icon be a summary of all the changes in all the repositories (like it is now)
2. Add such a summary (the blue ball with the white number on it) to the right of each collapsible list item header, while it is collapsed

data.title: Custom compose key configuration does not work

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.16.0 (787b31c0474e6165390b5a5989c9619e3e16f953, 2017-09-06T16:19:37.192Z)
- OS Version: Linux x64 4.9.0-3-amd64
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
latex-workshop|Jam|3.5.2
spellright|ban|1.1.40
jupyter|don|1.1.3
unicode-latex|oij|1.0.2


I have configured some custom keybindings for entering unicode symbols using the compose key. They work on other programs but not on vscode.

For example, the default "compose" + "." + "." does type "‚Ä¶", as expected. 
However my custom "compose" + "g" + "a", which should type "Œ±", as it does in other programs, does not work. 

A fix or a workarround would be welcomed.

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create an .XCompose file in the home directory with the line 
`<Multi_key> <g> <a> : "Œ±"`
2. Restart X.
3. "compose" + "g" + "a" types "Œ±" in most programs.
4. "compose" + "g" + "a" doesn't do anything on vscode.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Github Diff will allow single line undo

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version:
- OS Version:

Feature:
1. When user will preview the diff between newly saved file and previous copy they should be able to undo single line rather discard all the changes all together. May be beside each - or + button there could be a discard icon.

![diff of individual line](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/14817471/30365246-f32c0f08-9888-11e7-98b0-8063aec2f9d2.png)

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes/No

data.title: [css] @supports at-rule unknown
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.16.0 (787b31c0474e6165390b5a5989c9619e3e16f953, 2017-09-06T16:54:47.289Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 6.1.7601

---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Place in a CSS file:
```
@supports (-moz-appearance: none) {
	select { -moz-appearance:    none }
}
```
2. Press Ctrl Shift M to view Problems
3. VS Code reports the following error:
> severity: 'Error'
> message: 'at-rule unknown'

---

``@supports`` is documented at https://developer.mozilla.org/en/docs/Web/CSS/@supports and is supported by most browsers.

Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Source Safe Integration
data.body:
Can we please have Visual Source Safe integration?
Many of us have not bought into Git, or other 3rd party off-site source code control systems.
We like things simple.
Our code, safely in our network, behind closed doors, away from competitors.
But, we do not want the bloat of Visual Studio Enterprise or the crippled nature of VS Community edition.
Plus although VSS is old, it still works and is a no-nonsense source code control system, plus we have been using it for over 20 years, and have millions of lines of code held inside it.
Please?
